THE W I F E ' S SECRET

is unavoidably

T h e M e d i c a l C e r t i f i c a t e is subjoined
tr" Percy Street, January 8th, 1848.

'Sir,

" Far several days past I have been attending Mr: CHARLES

KEAN

with

my decided opinion, that the will be incapable of articulating distinctly by that day ; and I may
add, that in all probability she will not be able to appear for a weeh, and then not without care
and attention on her part, the weather at present being so unfavorable to her recovery.
This
account of Mrs. CHARLES
KEAN's health is communicated at the request of Mr. KEAN.
" 1 am, Sir, Your obedient Servant,
" B. Webster, Esq."
" JAMES
CLAYTON."

Vn petit fat—that's short and fat in English, Mr.
R O G E R S

kiudly undertakes to lend a band to play.

Pipkin and Rusty, (Heralds both, to Delph and Iron ling)
Into the action. Messrs. A. B R I N D A L and B R A I D will bring;
The Iron King, ("not he of Roils, the podgiest qfpodgers),
Vn petit fat—that's short and fat in English, Mr. R O G E R S .
People of China, Delphians, Lords, Ladies, Iron Guards,
By numerous Auxiliaries, whose names renown discards.
The Princess Carbon, (child of Coal) with both hands given away,
Miss R E Y N O L D S kindly undertakes to lend a hand to play;
The Countess Fossil, (Carbon's Maid of honour) by Miss C A R R E ,
Two Ladies (who don't say a word}—no matter who they are.
And, as the Fairy .Nightingale, who charm, the Public ear, -.
Araraans, Mr.. L. S. B U C K I W G H A M will appear.

JULLIEN.

Applications for Tickets to be made at t h e Box Office of t h e Haymarket Theatre.
T h e Tickets admit to both nights of performance at these prices:—Pit (the Stalls
removed for t h e occasion, and t h e Seats numbered), One Guinea each person; First and Second Tiers of Boxes, O n e Guinea each person; Amphitheatre and First and Second Rows
of Slips, T e n Shillings each person. Both nights included in each of these charges. Private Boxes (also admitting to both nights of performance) from £ 3 to £10 each box.
The doors will b e opened at half-past Six, and the performance will commence at half-past Seven precisely, by which time it is requested that the whole of the Company may be seated.
Directors of general Arrangements—Mr.

J O H N PAYNE COLLIER, M r . CHARLES KNIGHT, M r . P E T E R CUNNINGHAM, and T H E LONDON SHAKESPEARE HOUSE COMMITTEE.
Stage Manager—Ma.

CHARLES DICKENS.

The appearance of

Mr. & Mrs. CHARLES KEAN,
I n the popular P l a y of

THE WIFE'S SECRET.
Is unavoidably

P O S T P O N E D until MONDAY

NEXT.

May 2 0 t h . ia consequence of t h e Sudden Indisposition of
M R .
C H A R L E S
K E A

N

.

T H E MEDICAL CERTIFICATE :
" Percy Street, May2lst, 1848."
"1 hereby certify, that Mr. CHARLES
KEAN is confined to his bed from, severe
indisposition, and that consequently, it will be utterly impossible for him to appear for some
few days."
"JAMES
CLAYTON,
Surgeon.*
"B.
Webster, Esq., Theatre Royal,
Hay-Market."

Lord Chamberlain's
Office,
May 28th, 1848.

In consequence of the Death of Her Royal
Highness the PRINCESS SOPHIA, the Lord
Chamberlain requires that the Little Theatre in
the Haymarket be Closed this Evening. (Monday)
and again on the Evening of the Funeral.

NE F I T
NTR E E T - O R D l l l i L I E S ,
I n favor of t h e E m p l o y m e n t ot t h e P o o r as

BY THE NATIONAL

*

JLssociatiOM.

It i, impossible for any one who ha, not de rotod a portion of hit time to an eaqairy into the
condition of the Peor. to form any conception of the extent of their physical sufferiag and social
degradation. Fifty Thousand Persons, on th. evidence of the Lord Mayor of London, rise daily from
their beds in this wealthy and luxurious Metropolis, not knowing where to gel theirfirstmeal. There
are now Forty Thousand honest hardworking industrious mechanics and labouring men entirely
thrown out ot work, and Thirty Thousand who are employed from Two to Three days only during
the week; the whole Seventy Thousand, beta.; compelled, from their necessities, either to sell their
furniture and their clothing, or become inmates of the rarious Unions and Workhouses. Some idea
may be formed of the mental agonies and heart-rending trials endured by the unemployed Poor, by
peruing the awful disclosures of an interview between the Right Honourable Lord Ashley, M.P. and
Two Hundred and Seven professed Thieves, in July last, who solicited his advice and protection, in
order that they might be assisted to lead honest lives. The whole details of this distressing consultation may be had gratis at 40, Leicester Square.
It is pleasing to be able to record the following anecdote in proof of the inherent good qualities
in an Englishman's breast, be be ever so humble or so poor ! " On the Evening that the Scavenging
Contractor for St. James's Parish had adopted his unfeeling measure, which threw the StreetOrderlies out of employment, Four destitute women were brought to the St. Bernard Hospice, in Ham
(Yard, from a Police Office, in order to have shelter for the night. The beds being all pre-engaged,
there was no means of affording the protection needed, and as in too many previous instances, they
-could not be admitted. The Street-Orderlies were at this moment at their sapper, and it was r e marked by the Superintendent, that an Inspector was visiting them all successively * a conversation in
whisper, was carried on amongst them; & on after enquiry he bad the satisfaction to hear that they had
subscribed sufficient money u> procure the Four destitute women a good lodging and a comfortable supper
besides." This noble act of spontaneous benevolence was performed by men who had jast been
thrown out of work, and did not know but that on the morrow they might themselves have needed the
v.ry money which they were giving away.
Surely then it is unjiut, nay cruel, to say or to think, because men are poor and fallen in the
fecial scale, they have not the same sympathies and feeling, as the more fortunate of mankind.
It is on behalf of Thousands of Poor, possessed of hearts as generous asth.se Street-Orderlies,
that this Night's Benefit is freely undertaken, and Hope whispers to the Philanthropist, " t h e appeal
•ball not be made in vain."

Mr.
Mrs

R A R L
E
AND

CHARLES
